title: How does the USA have systemic racism? - Quora

response.answer_text: Here it’s necessary to know what “systemic racism” is. It’s a group to group power relation where people in positions of power — managers, bank loan officers, landlords and real estate agents, police and prosecutors — tend to act in ways that limit or deny equality of access to resources to the racialized group — a group treated in practice as an “inferior race” who can be treated worse — even if the persona making the relevant decisions — about hiring, loans, whatever — isn’t necessarily explicitly aware in their own thinking that their decision fits in with this pattern. So it’s a situation where power is exercized by people who belong to one group over members of another group, in ways that disadvantage the subordinate group. Managers, landlords, judges, prosecutors tend to be overwhelmingly white. This practice in the USA can be traced back to the campaigns of the colonial elite in North America to justify the introduction of the institution of life-time slavery for people of African ancestry — which involved major campaigns referring to blacks as inferiors and thus their worse status being justified. There are various studies that show these patterns still exist — race discrimination in hiring, in bank lending, in renting or selling houses, in sentencing practices by judges, in behavior of cops and prosecutors, such as racial profiling in traffic stops. These practices tend to sustain an unequal situation for the African-American population, which started out in a propertyless situation after liberation from slavery, and then were subjected to a century of official racial segregation and discrimination policies. Although some gains were made during the civil rights era. Various laws were passed making certain forms of discrimination illegal (but often without effective forms of enforcement), and popular attitudes towards the black population by the white population changed significantly — with declines in support for a variety of racist stereotypes, declines in things like wanting your kids to not be in schools with blacks, declines in opposition to inter-racial marriage. Also, there was the emergence since the ’60s of a sizeable black professional-managerial class and black celebrities and athletes are more visible than in the past. But this hasn’t ended the pattern of racial inequality, such as blacks having twice the unemployment rate as whites. So systemic racism is revealed in racial inequality still being a major fact of life. Blacks are three times more likely to be poor than whites. Average income of blacks is about 40 percent less than whites. On average, blacks have about one-eighth of the net worth of whites. The pattern of power I referred to earlier helps to explain the persistence of this inequality. The question asks about where this pattern persists. It persists throughout the USA. To look at where it would be worse, you’d have to look at various statistics, such as degree of racial segregation (worse probably in places like Chicago and Milwaukee) or other statistical evidence to get an idea of the real circumstances faced by the black population in that area. There are other groups in USA who experience forms of systemic racism, to one degree or another — it affects American Indians and some Latino groups also. But black Americans are the “canary in the mine” as far as this pattern in USA is concerned.
